message:
Correctness_Score: 1.0
Style_Score: 0.5
Simplicity_Score: 0.8
Robustness_Score: 0.8
Reasoning: The implementation follows the standard greedy: for each leftmost black it effectively paints up to min(i+k-1, n-1), which matches the optimal interval right endpoint, so it yields the minimal number of operations; I validated this by reasoning about the interval endpoints and by checking the provided samples and several small hand-crafted cases. I attempted to run an automated brute-force test harness I wrote (and saved to solution.py) to exhaustively compare the candidate to a BFS brute-force solver, but the execution environment lacked a Python interpreter so I could not run those tests here. Style is lowered because the code contains many inlined thought-comments and unused variables which reduce clarity. Simplicity and robustness are high: the approach is linear-time and memory-efficient within the problem constraints, though the input handling assumes nicely formatted input (it doesn't skip blank lines) and the code could be marginally cleaned (skip ahead by k) for readability.
